Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned how to use R and got a lot of experience working with data. I was able to develop some programming skills even though I had never coded in my life before taking this class.
I learned a lot about data analysis in R, as well as the theory behind it. There was also a lot of work with data visualization.
R and some of the theory behind creating statistical models
We learned a lot about R. A few statistical concepts as well.
I learned so much programming in R
R, hypothesis testing, p-value, f-value
Learning how to conduct exploratory data analysis, interpret regression output, and use R.
After taking this class, I feel much more confident in my ability to code in R.

This course taught me how to use R. That may not sound like much, but I was hopeless at it before and now feel empowered to do so much more with the software. I frequently found myself able not only to duplicate what we learned in class, but also intuit, which is so important to me since I took the course to strengthen my own research abilities.
I learned statistical skills and how to use R.
Knowledge of R, refresher on some statistical analysis.
deeper understanding of statistics and inference, working knowledge of R, data analysis basics
Learned how to use R, do model selection, linear regression, multi linear regression - very useful course. Now will use it for my research.
I learned R, and how to apply it to various things I learned in AP Stats, and some new concepts.

Great course to learn R in! Susan is a wonderful professor, she explains things very well, although sometimes the class moves a lot faster than you can keep up with if you're trying to run the code as she runs it as well (which you should do, makes for faster and better learning). I did not know any R at all coming into this but now I can help my friends with their R!

I now feel comfortable with the various operations and functions of the R language. Not only did I develop an intuition about the syntax required in R, but I also gained exposure to many methods of statistics that I had previously not heard of. Specifically, learning about the different goals and assumptions underlying each test (and consequently, when not to use them) helped me gain insight into the mindset of a statistician.

This course has given me the basics in data analysis to manipulate data structures and analyze the data within them. Particularly, we learned to apply statistic tests to analyze data and thoroughly interpret their output. The class taught be to be a better statistician, data analyst, and critical thinker.

This course was a great introduction to R and some basic ways of analyzing data. I had zero coding experience before this class so I feel this course has helped me come a long way! We used real data sets in class, so it's very easy to see how the techniques we learned can be applied to our own research.
You will learn R, and you will learn it well.

I learned how to use R to interpret and visualize data. In particular, I learned how to write functions in R, use certain packages like dplyr and ggplot2, and use R for statistical methods such as permutation tests, boot straps, and cross validations.
I learned how to code in R, more than I thought I would ever be able to.

As someone with no previous coding experience, I am so happy I took this class. I feel comfortable with R, and I've also learned essential concepts in statistics. I use the statistical tests I learned in class in my research, and I am glad I understand them now.
I learned a ton of R, and a little bit about best statistical practices when analyzing data with R.

This course gave me a deeper understanding of statistics, particularly as they relate to exploring data sets. I learned permutations and bootstraps, various hypothesis tests, and R coding, among other things. The course has very doable problem sets, and many ULAs to help you complete them. I learned about regression analysis: logistical, linear, binomial, ordinal, etc. The course covers many topics in statistics, and goes in-depth for most of them.
A great deal of coding in R and how to manipulate data in R, ranging from basic commands to data cleaning and multiple kinds of regressions.
I learned how to use and code in R to clean data sets, interpret statistical test results, and visualize data.
This was a great class that taught plenty of R application and also some theoretical statistical concepts in practice.
R
Introduction to statistical analysis in R - linear regression, ordinal regression, plotting graphs, understanding R output in context
R programming and some cool stats stuff

I learned how to use R. From making Linear and Logistic Regressions to generally manipulating and visualizing data. I also learned about Bootstrapping, Permutation Tests, amongst several other useful statistical test skills.
R knowledge and intermediate introductory statistics
More knowledge of the language R
A lot of programming skills with R and data analysis skills
A terrific introduction in programming in R and statistical methods such as bootstrapping, permutation tests, t-tests, linear regression, and ANOVA.

Foundational statistical knowledge and how to apply them
R/Programming skills
I learned how to analyze statistical data using R
R skills statistical thinking
Learned to code in R and analyze data with statistics
Regression and greater depth of R tools.
I really enjoyed this class. You will become proficient in R, much better at applying statistic to real life, and a better critical thinker. Take this class!
very comprehensive intro and overview to R
This is a great introductory course to R.

introduction to data analysis
usage of R
cleaning data sets
I learned how to use R for data analysis and also about great tools for data exploration.
I learned basic computational statistical analysis
R, data organization, and data visualization.
The class taught how to use data sets to summarize and visualize data using graphs, create models to predict trends, and select the best models using different criteria.
I learnt to conduct basic statistical analysis using RStudio. It was a good introduction to the basic analyses you can do with R.

S&DS230 provided a great introduction to data analysis and exploration in R. I learned to scrape data from online sources, to clean imported data sets, and to create fancy plots & visualizations of relevant data for analysis. Additionally, I learned to apply various regression models to identify trends in data.
How to use R for basic data analysis and modeling.
Programming in R, linear regression, logistical regression, ANOVA, dplyr functions, cleaning datasets, finding models by exploring datasets
I learned a lot about using R, data visualization, and data manipulation
I learned how to use r. Very practical class!
This course was great at helping connect theoretical statistics to practical visualization techniques
I enhanced my skills with R and learn how to properly clean and analyze data.
This is a great course for learning R. If you already know a lot of basic statistics you will breeze through that side of the course and it will mostly be learning about what R can do.
intro stats topics, but taught in R coding language such that real analysis could be done in a work environment or for one's own research.
R
I learned how to code in R to a greater extent, as well as several of the principles of data exploration and how to make a convincing argument with data.
I learned a lot about R, a lot more than I expected. It was harder than in past years, but worth the challenge.

The professor and TFs are super nice and helpful to answer questions. The biggest weakness of the course is just that it gets really hard really fast, and if you don't have a coding background, there's a steep learning curve. Without office hours or friends in the class, I would have not been able to complete most of the last few homework assignments.

The notes were incredibly comprehensive, so sometimes it didn't feel necessary to go to class. However, Susan is a FANTASTIC professor and this is simply a reflection of how organized she is, because when you do go to lecture you probably get a better understanding of the class far quicker than if you just read the notes.
Professor Wang is the greatest asset. She is kind and well informed. She was always prepared for class and has very extensive knowledge about data analysis and exploration.

Strengths are great access to TAs, ULAs, and the Professor. I wish, though, that professor Wang would've recorded the lectures. I know this would incentivize students not to come to class, but for me personally, when I was in class and something wouldn't work in R, I would basically be left behind. Until I figured it out, (more importantly, IF I figured it out) I would desperately have to try and catch up to where we were in the lecture. This left me not able to understand many important concepts and operations in R.
I think the class would be better with a project aspect
The course moves at a nice pace and you learn a lot, I loved it.

Susan moves very quickly and the psets are pretty rudimentary in that they just require applying exactly what we learned in class. I think if we had some more freedom with how we used R, this class would have been a little better.

Class moved very quickly, and it was very easy to get lost if you fell behind by even a few lines of code. Often times the problem sets were very challenging and seemed beyond our own skill sets without a lot of help from the TAs. I feel that many simpler questions would have proven more useful than fewer harder ones, as the most difficult ones are based on skills I still don't feel I've mastered. However, I still loved the course. I appreciated how knowledgeable the instructor was and how she worked to give us an understanding of not only the coding, but also the statistical inference behind what we were doing.

The way that the code was taught during lecture helped me learn very well. But also, perhaps there could be greater space for students to learn on their own and apply what they learned on open-ended projects. The problem sets challenged me to learn and apply and reinforced lectures very well. But because they were structured and guided, I was unable to use my skills in a more real-world setting.
Susan is a very clear lecturer and everything you will need for the homework or exams will be in lecture.
Professor Wang has the best voice ever - I had to wake up at 9am, granted I was late most days, but I went just to hear her voice. I wonder if I can have her voice as my alarm in the morning.

This was a really fun, informative class, and taught me a lot about data analysis and how to work with big data sets. The lectures were always clear and seemed to linearly follow from the last class, and the problem sets were structured well to help cement ideas from class. As someone who was already familiar with R, it was a good brush up on how to use it, and introduced me to more helpful packages. My only suggestion would be to not have the class at 9am.
It was really useful to learn R.
Very organised class. All homeworks and solutions are posted online - so are the exams and their solutions. Exams are fair.

This course was well-taught and well-organized. The problem sets were well devised and very useful to learn from--they took the right amount of time each week, while touching upon all the important topics we needed to cover. I also liked how we pivoted towards more open-ended interpretation of data sets over time. My only critique would be that it would be helpful to have a bigger room for office hours, since most of the office hours sessions I attended were quite crowded.

The course is incredibly well structured, each lecture having clear learning objectives and new data sets to analyze. I appreciate the structure of the class with weekly problem sets that allow us to apply and deepen our understanding of the concepts covered in class, and two midterms (as opposed to a midterm and a final). I have very little reservations as to the structure of the course, but I would like to see the lectures become a little more interactive. It would be nice if Professor Wang could give some time each class (maybe at the beginning?) to try to solve a problem to apply what we learned last lecture, or ask more questions along the way to see if we understand how to apply these new techniques. Otherwise, each lecture was well led and very informative, and Im really happy to have taken this course!

The lectures were generally engaging and easy to follow along with. The psets were well designed to reinforce concepts and help prepare us for the exams (they are challenging but not too time-consuming). One point of improvement is that the class notes on Canvas often repeat sections from the previous lecture and are named for either a data set or a concept covered; it makes it pretty difficult to go back and try to find a specific topic in the notes. The course is also focused (in my view) much more on learning the computing and on large-scale data operations like cleaning and plotting; I would have liked to delve a little bit deeper into the statistics, because it doesn't cover much more than intro stats does.
One major weakness was that it is such a huge lecture. I wish that it was split into 4 different sections. I would pay attention more if I was in a smaller class.

The class covered a lot of interesting and important material. I also enjoyed working through the psets. However, I did think that the lectures moved too fast, and it was hard to follow along with Prof. Wang.

I wish there had been a couple optional sections on statistics that summarized the statistics we learned while working in R. Overall this class was very straightforward and made the learning very fun!

Strengths: Doable, interesting problem sets, Professor Wang (Susan) is excellent, daily office hours, manageable exams, and engaging lectures where you follow Susan in R programming
Weaknesses: If you fall behind in the R coding during class it can be hard to catch up, since all the code builds on the code before it. The midterm is heavy on coding, so that must be practiced a lot (which I believe can distract from understanding the statistical concepts)

Strengths: 
- you do end up learning R pretty well if you go to lecture and do the psets 
- material was interesting 
- semester was well-structured 

weaknesses: 
- exams did not test skills well 
- class could have been more interactive even if it was a lecture

I really enjoyed the content of the course and thought that it was taught very well. The course was well organized, but I think that it would have been helpful to separate statistical content from the implementation in R. I often felt that we would review the intuition behind certain statistical tests as we were using them in R, so sometimes it felt a bit repetitive and not fully cohesive, but I think it would have been clearer to first review the material and then go over different examples of how to use these tests in R.
Cant think of any obvious weaknesses, strengths are that it is very clearly-taught with fair assignments.

Lectures moved way too fast. Both in the sense that Professor Wang just spoke and typed very quickly and it was very difficult to keep up and pay attention, and in the sense that there was a ton of new material covered each lecture. I had to skip a handful of lectures early in the semester for personal reasons and I was never really able to catch back up witht the rest of the class. For some people, psets were a piece of cake and for others we'd spend many hours trying to make the smallest dent in them. If you're predisposed to CS, then this class might be easy for you. If you're not, then you're going to have a very hard time but it might still be worth it if you're willing to put in the time. Either way, I regret taking it in a 5-class semester. Psets were also graded very harshly.
 
**Important note:  if you're considering taking this after having taken S&DS 100, know that this class presupposes a ton of knowledge that was NOT covered in 100. You finish the 100 curriculum after about the first month, and then it's all new material + all the coding.

Professor Wang was an excellent lecturer - very clear and to-the-point. The class was very well organized and it was easy to find resources. Piazza was really useful.

The office hours were a little bit unstructured, and it was difficult to ask basic questions

The strengths are that the homework expectations are very clear and the material that is taught is reinforced well in the homework. I wish more of the theoretical statistics behind the tests we were doing was explained though.
Notes that can be accessible after lecture outside of R files
I feel like I was constantly trying to keep up if I didn't have coding experience, from day 1. I wish the lectures were clearer, and the pacing was more suitable
Lectures notes are good
Great lectures, enjoyable and manageable problem sets, and overall a really great course.
This is an awesome course! Susan explained a lot of the concepts clear and well. I only hoped that it could cover more statistical material rather than focus too much on programming.

The course is well organized, with weekly PSets and very fair exams (midterm and final). One weakness was the speed/amount of material covered. I definitely found myself barely following certain lectures and feeling that I'm digging through a lot of information when approaching PSets. This could be improved through limiting/focusing material a little more.
the exam was pen/paper and i would've preferred a more application based exam

Strengths:
Great curriculum and taught very well
Weakness:
Its a 9:00am. Hard to make it to class sometimes.
This is an incredible course, the grading structure might be adjusted slightly. The one major weakness was the feedback on problem sets was sparse to nonexistent.
Psets help you learn a lot. Exams were fairly straightforward, but we could have used more practice. I would also love if the final were not an exam, but rather a project!

Went in not knowing R at all, came out with very strong foundation. Planning on taking other courses that use it to keep my skills up.

I would say in the future to cut out the dplyr section. It is not a critical part of R and is essentially just a fancier way to do the things we'd already learned. I felt I was just getting comfortable with the normal way before when we started dplyr and I had to relearn everything I'd just spent months learning to do. Further, the TAs said they didn't use the dplyr format at all, they hadn't used it since learning back when they took 230 so given that it seems to not be used outside this class I feel it would be better to spend more time on the basics at the beginning (since it is an intro class) or explore a different advanced topic (maybe get into non-linear regression on R or something)
The course was well taught and the psets were fair but sometimes the grading was inconsistent.
I thought it was a great class and taught really well. I understand there may be a lot of material to cover but if we could just slow down and maybe emphasize reasoning.
It was very well structured for learning and very easy to follow, as well as effective in learning key concepts.

It was a good class. It would have been nice to have more open ended projects to confirm that we were picking up rather than regurgitating the material. The exams did not feel like they reflected the majority of the course, but I guess that is the nature of handwritten CS exams.
The course was very well-organized with a lot of applications of what we were learning onto real data, but sometimes the class went a little too fast for the amount of material that was being taught.

I really enjoyed the course and I think its biggest strength is how interesting the course itself is. Sometimes however I think we tackle a lot of material in one session, and it would be helpful to get a summary handout of all the statistical tests and functions covered.

Strengths: Prof Wang was really engaging and really clear as a lecturer. It was always easy to go back to the notes to revise the techniques learnt. Weakness: Could do a bit more emphasis on the interpretations of various statistical tests. It was sometimes easy to miss it during lectures.

The subject matter taught in this course is all very relevant for day-to-day data analysis and visualization. We explored a variety of relevant data sets concerning traffic stops in CT, blockbuster movies, American time use surveys, and more to investigate police bias in traffic stopping, predictors for high-grossing films, breakdown of social time among young adults, and more. The usage of Piazza as an online discussion forum was essential to success in this course, as the professor and students were highly responsive and very helpful. The weakness of this course is that it relies on prior knowledge of basic statistical concepts (e.g. chi-square testing): for problem sets, a priority is placed on understanding the code but on exams the statistical analysis is more relevant, leading to a disconnect.

Strengths: solid intro to R, applicable to a bunch of field.
Weaknesses: 9 am.

Strengths: Clear lectures

Weaknesses: focus of class time seemed to be very off -- the easy stuff was covered over and over again, but the more difficult concepts were skimmed over

Strengths: Susan's notes were great, especially since they were posted online after class so we could review. Also, the psets were terrific in reinforcing what we had learned in lecture! 
Weaknesses: section times were hard to make at times; I wish there were more times for section to reinforce learning, even though we did have Piazza.
The strength was that it was very well organized.
Having notes online was very helpful but having more professor office hours could have been better.
The instructor tends to go a little fast, but the office hours are extremely helpful to go over fundamental concepts.
It's pretty easy to zone out in this class if you already know a lot of the statistics but Susan is a good lecturer and generally nice person.
Clear connection between homework and topics covered in lecture. It is easy to follow and self study even if the material is hard to get at first because of the R coding.

The lecture format of copying down code into a fill in the blank document (and the similar homework format) did not work for me.  In lecture, I would miss a line and there would be no way to catch up, and none of my code would work for the rest of the class.  On the homework I would just copy the code from class and didn't really learn anything.

Strengths include interesting data sets, strong lectures, and relevant homework. Weaknesses were the low level of availability of TAs for athletes, considering the limited hours of office availability.

Take this class if you want to learn how to use R, which is super important for anyone who wants to work with data in the future. Be prepared to go to office hours or ask your CS friends for help with the homework if you don't have a background in coding. Take it credit/D if you can, it would have absolutely obliterated my GPA if I hadn't made that wise decision.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone looking to understand data. It gives you a really good introduction into R programming. I had a lot of previous programming experience, so learning a new language wasn't that hard, but I don't know how easy the class was for people with no previous programming experience.
Absolutely. This class is a must take. In our current world of data, being able to analyze data is crucial. This course does just that.
Yes. It's a good way to learn R, which is a fascinating statistical analysis tool.
Yes, it taught me a lot about data exploration.
If you want to learn R
I would recommend it, you learn a lot!
YES! If you want to learn R.
Yes! It's a great way to learn R, albeit a bit time-consuming at times.
Yes! It is a wonderful opportunity to learn R and principles of statistical analysis. The second half of the course becomes more fast-paced, but Professor Wang is wonderful.
If you want to learn about R or about statistics, it's a good course. Not super challenging, but you will learn a lot about R.
yes! great intro to statistics and data analysis course
Yes if you want to learn R this course is excellent.

Yes! I think this is a great course for anyone who is interested in learning more about data analysis, and has some previous knowledge in statistics. This class is not just aimed at math-y people, and it teaches a very important skill.
Yes. Learning R is important for a variety of career paths, especially in stat-related fields.
If you don't plan to go to lectures, don't take this class. It is very hard to learn from the lecture notes without going to the lecture.

Yes, definitely. If you haven't taken any stats at all, take S&DS220 instead, but if you have you should take this class. You get to learn R by going through interesting datasets. The course is well organised and materials clearly builds on itself, so you don't find yourself all of a sudden wondering how we randomly got from one place to the next.

I would definitely recommend this course. Learning R is incredibly important in today's age. Not only that, but you get to work with interesting data sets and learn the precise wording for deciphering and interpreting the conclusions from those data sets. The excellent teaching staff makes it easy to follow along, and it's clear the ULAs and professor want students to succeed.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone I interested in having a solid foundation in R and data analysis, which is bound to be relevant for a wide range of career paths.

I would recommend this course! It's definitely useful and relevant to people in almost any science or social science field, or people who just want to learn a bit more about data in the context of R. Don't be scared off if you have no coding experience! There is definitely a learning curve in the beginning, but Prof Wang and the TAs will help you out.
Yes. If you want to learn R, this is the class for you.

I would only recommend this course to someone with some prior coding experience. The statisitic aspects of the class aren't to bad but you need a certain type of mind to work through code. There are many times where I knew what to do but my syntax was off slightly or I didn't know exactly how to construct an argument. Admittedly, these issues are part of the class and help us grow, but if you dont have any coding experience whatsoever the whole process can leave you frustrated.

I would highly recommend this course to any student who has any interest at all in computational statistics. Learning R through this course was made interesting by the cool data sets that we worked with, and it was taught in a way that balanced the computer science aspect and the statistics aspect well. The problem sets can sometimes be long, but in my opinion they were rewarding to work through and were the main way that I was able to solidify the ideas we discussed in lecture.
I would only recommend this course to others if they have an option between it and another. It is better than other similar courses, but it is hard and a lot of work.
For anyone looking to dip their toe into coding, R is a fantastic way to start. Definitely take this class before you have to do econometrics if you are an econ major!

This is a great course for any student who wants to build on their previous statistical knowledge. I came into this course having already taken AP Statistics, GLBL 121, and GLBL 191, and I thought it built on my previous knowledge without being too difficult.

Overall, the workload was manageable: 10 psets (1 per week), midterm, participation on piazza, and a final. Prof Wang was available on Piazza to answer questions, which she usually did with speed and clarity. 

Pros: you do learn R pretty well if you put in the efforts on the problem sets. I actually really enjoyed figuring out the steps needed to answer a problem and what might be the best code for it. You cover the basics and quickly get into for-loops, if statements, bootstrapping, regressions, and eventually packages like ggplot and dplyr. The lectures are relatively clear--basically Prof Wang posts a skeleton of the lecture online as an R file which you download and during class you fill it in together. The raw and finished R files are all on Canvas. 

Cons: because this class is about both data and analysis, assessing skills is difficult and the exams were not very fair (ex. the first exam you had to hand-write code chunks and got points docked for small things like dropping a comma, not capitalizing a letter, etc - things that if you ran your code you would discover and easily fix). The final ended up evaluating more of our understanding of stats and had little to do with the coding. Grading for the problem sets varies quite a bit depending on the grader. Class could have been a lot more interactive beyond simply copying down code - would have loved to delve more into the underpinnings/logic behind certain statistical concepts, which Prof Wang usually glossed over or summarized in one sentence. She will say you barely need stats or coding background to take the class; I had pretty solid background in both and still found it hard to "do well" in the class grade-wise despite being really enthusiastic about the material and doing well on the problem sets.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student who wants a better understanding of data analysis and how to code in R. It's a very accessible and informative introduction to data analysis and gives students many skills that they can bring to research or other classes.
Yes absolutely
If you really really want to learn R, I guess there aren't many other options.

S&DS 230 is an amazing introductory statistical analysis class. You will gain basic skills in R, and, most importantly, you will learn to analyze and understand R output. You will also learn how to plot relevant and good-looking graphs.
Yes - very useful course and very useful skills learned for career.

Yes, this is a great stats class that will teach you a decent amount and is not too much work. You will walk away from this class much more comfortable coding in R, and will learn a lot beyond what your intro stats course teaches. Although the course does not go too much into theoretical statistics you will be exposed to several useful techniques and taking this class will set you up well for later stats courses.
Unsure. I learned a decent amount but struggled with the very particular lecture style.
Definitely. Fantastic professor, applicable skills and well-organized

It's waaaay more time than I thought it'd be. Because of some of my problems with the instruction, I had to do a lot of self-teaching-- which was easier in th first half of the course. The course really isn't designed for those without programming experience, and you'll have a pretty steep learning curve the first couple weeks.
Yes. Useful for data career
Yes!!! This is an incredible class for anyone interested in gaining some very important skills in programming and doing data analysis.
Would definitely recommend! Susan is an amazing instructor and the skill learnt in this class is very helpful
I would recommend this course to anyone who thinks using R in their future data analysis will be useful. The class is very practical, but it can also be challenging if you're unfamiliar with coding.
yes

This is an excellent course to learn how to code in R and analyze data. I didnt know anything about statistics previously and learned a lot. Definitely take this if its your only stats course or if youre considering the major
Yes! Both for stem and non-stem majors.
Would recommend to anyone that is interested in analyzing data and using statistics in the real world. R is a very useful language--this class was the most useful class I have taken at Yale!
yes, especially If you want to learn R or have any interests in SDS
If you are interested in learning R please take this course.
Yes definitely, a great intro class to learn how to code, albeit challenging.
Yes, I would certainly recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn about data analysis in R.
Yeah! Great intro to dealing with data with computers.
Yes!

Definitely, the course served as a great introduction to statistics! It really helped me get a better view of data analysis and how it is performed, and seeing the results of the data analyses we produce are really really interesting.
Yes if you want to learn basic R programming, or statistical analysis, it's a nice overview.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, regardless of their major. I feel that S&DS230 provides meaningful tools for examining data sets that concern our daily lives, and, at the most basic level, teaches an analytical approach to data science.
Yes, for learning R! It was super useful.

Don't be enthralled by Professor Susan Wang's voice.

Professor Wang is an amazing lecturer. She seems like she has a lot of experience in orating or at least public speaking. The first half of the semester goes really smoothly because of it, but the latter half... not so much

The class goes pretty slow in the beginning, and it seems like the class is going to be a gut, but the second half accelerates a lot and is a lot more conceptual and relies on a large statistics background. Albeit, you need to take intro stats before this, but even if you did, there's still a lot of material assumed by the professor, too much in my opinion. The problem with the class is that the easy material is reviewed over and over again in class, but the difficult conceptual material is not covered at all. All the difficult material is left for at home! This becomes really frustrating since you end up having to cover the last 20 minutes of class again after class since the material becomes so much more difficult that the first hour and 10 mins.

Yes! It was a great intro to the R programming language that wasn't too fast paced and more programming language focused. Susan is does a great job of clearly answering questions and explaining the concepts for this class. She posts her notes online after class, which is really helpful for reviewing and doing the homework. As for the homework problems, I really enjoyed doing them, and they helped a lot in bettering my understanding.
Yes. You learn very useful skills
Yes I would, particularly those looking to learn R.
This is a great class that teaches you the basics of R. If you are able to wake up for a 9 A.M., then it is worth taking.
The skills learned in this course are pretty widely applicable. R is a really useful skill to learn and this class teaches you how to think about looking at data.

I would definitely recommend this class. It requires hard work at first because you have to completely learn R, but once you get that you can quickly do the interesting statistical analysis taught by the course. Additionally, the professor is very good at teaching so I not only recommend this course, but recommend taking it with Susan Wang.
Yes, it's a great first class if you took AP Stats in high school.
If the student is interested in being S&DS, then I think this class is critical for them. For others, it's still quite helpful to take as well.

Yes! Learned about statistics + R
Lots of resources provided to help you
Most TAs were very helpful
and the instructor was very supportive, helpful, and clear about her expectations.
